Not much of an anime fan, but I... APPRECIATE this movie. Lots of action but a bit of a incomprehensive, illogical story about a mad ex-soldier looking to take over THE WORLD with a macrobot powder. It's up to some space bounty hunters to thwart him and save the world!

Superb adaptation of the classic anime series that continues the story with some brilliant animation, excellent voice acting and an exploration of deeper themes.  The cast remains excellent, making the entire crew a brilliant mix of anti-heroes who care about each other even if they don't want to admit it.  The filmmakers also continue the great work of the show, and while it is essentially an overblown episode of the series, it delivers in scope and action.  Plus, since it takes place during Halloween, a great addition for any October rotation.

The animation is great just like the tv show but it's interesting. My issue with the tv show is it's too fast by introducing a villain and 20 minutes later they're dead. Here we have a deep more thought out hour and 20 something minutes of greatness. It is slow at times but in the end seeing the gang and of course spike spegal again is good as always.

The art was amazing and while I had a few issues with the continuity of the film, I was pleased by the plot and the extra characters were very well written. As usual this universe leaves us with questions, but that is the beauty of Cowboy Bebop.

Great animation, well-designed antagonist and some really good fight scenes. The only letdown is that it turns out to be a "the entire world hangs in the balance" scenario, which doesn't really suit the Bebop crew and their usual affairs. Still, the first half of the movie is undeniably fantastic!

8.0. Bebop the Movie is able to deliver something that lines exactly as the series does. The movie creates an episode-like feeling where it explores a philosophical approach towards the world, all while exploding the screen with action and drama. Though it's not strong enough to stand alone, Bebop the movie is able to develop the series further with an even cleaner style of animation that truly looks one of a kind.

Cowboy Bebop is visual eye-candy. It's a genre-defining piece that deserves it place in animation history. The world it opens the viewer up to is unlike anything most viewers see.

But this movie feels out of place in the Cowboy Bebop universe.

Understand, the soundtrack, visuals, and animation quality was stellar. Each scene is astonishing. Everything about this movie I loved. Yet, the story, plot, and characters seemed out of place. Things that weren't introduced or done in the series was done in the movie.

When has Spike ever flirted with other women in the series? He had a thing for Julia and Julia only. Who seriously says "your friendly neighborhood bounty hunter?" What happened to Elektra(?) after the end of the movie? So many questions unresolved.

Most of the movie seems to be more of a fanfic than an actual piece of the Cowboy Bebop universe. A cash grab for the fanboys, of course.

4/5. It's a great movie. You'll enjoy it too, giving that you're able to hold your suspension of belief as the crew travels around space not-New York.
This movie was such a treat! I'll take any more Cowboy Bebop content - these characters are just that good.

Just watch it if you like it thank me later but if not at least you will see something different and original (mix a lot of stiles and create their own stile). It is not a boring remake that everyone know how it will ends.
This film was great.

I urge anyone to watch this! Great movie from a great series. I think the 26 episodes are on Netlix. No I don't work for Netflix but alot of movies are easily accessible on that platform. The show is very unique and reaches a wide variety of audiences because of deep philosophical themes of existentialism, loneliness and fate. I also think memory in relation to the human psyche and learning how to best cope with tragedy and loss. Which reminds me that I should definitely revisit this wonderful animated feature that has an excellent cast of voices such as Steve Blum and Beau Billingslea. I've heard of a live adaptation of this movie and won't be surprised if it comes out in the near future. I'm not just speaking about the movie in his review I'm actually speaking of the entire series however this is only a site that rates movies so yea. It gives you a great appreciation for jazz and music and being cool can come in all shapes and sizes. So remember when you watch this movie or the series for the first time this is Holy Animated Material also called HAM.

The movie is a let down for me and although it is gorgeous and well made, it was not a great movie and I was ready for it to end.

Fan and casual viewer's alike will probably enjoy this feature-length bonus film. It sports the hallmarks of a great movie OVA such as clever writing, interesting new characters, fluid animation and an emphasis on storytelling. The latter is done so in a way that perhaps overly padded, as anime in general has a knack for always trying to engage the viewer's emotional, existential thoughts, but it's a fun romp for anyone who loves Cowboy Bebop and wants a bit more after the end of the original run. Also, there's Ein, and you can never have too much of Ein.

Not bad, but I found the movie had some slight pacing issues especially in the middle half. Cowboy Bebop The Movie takes place between episodes 22 and 23 of the original run of the show. You don't really have to know much about the show or in this case watched it to enjoy the movie, but hey it helps. The film follows a bounty hunter crew led by Spike Spiegel (Steve Blum), his right hand man Jet Black (Beau Billingslea), Faye Valentine (Wendee Lee) a young lady that joined them early on in the show and works with them, and Edward Wong (Melissa Fahn) a young kid with super great hacking abilities. The movie centers around the crew tracking down Vincent Volaju (Daran Norris) a terrorist that was the sole survivor of a genetic experiment on Titan. Vincent is trying to release a microvirus that will kill millions. Spike teams up with Vincents ex-lover Electra Ovirowa (Jennifer Hale) who actually works for the same medical company that experimented on Vincent. Together Spike and Electra work together to stop Vincent before its too late. The movie's animation is great. Since it came out after the series ended the animation is presented in wide screen HD and it's definitely a step above the shows animation. The movie has a pretty good plot, but I found it took too long to get into the meat of the plot. In typical Anime fashion they wasted about the first 40 minutes to get to the point. The show's original episodes were 22-24 minutes long so jumping to a movie thats almost 2 hours they lost a bit of the fast pacing they usually had. I still enjoyed it overall. Although, the movie basically only follows Spike (Jet, Faye and Edward all take a back seat on thus one) I still found it enjoyable. Fans of the show probably have already seen this, but if not definitely give it a look!

but the movie didn't lived up to our expectations from the anime, the dialogues and style are a bit more classy than it should have been, the plot is alright starts to feel a bit plain sometimes, but the action is what we wanted, its a must watch for cowboy bebop fans others should watch the anime series first. The characters Spike, Jet, Faye, Ed,and Ein are a pleasure to watch, still to say this movie is nothing compared to the anime series.

I actually watched the movie first before the 26-episode anime series, and loved each of the main cast's unique character. I love that there is ethnic and cultural diversity in the film, with the plot being in-line with the series on the concept of "dream & reality"

For those of you who know me, you know I'm a big anime fan, and one of my favorite series is Cowboy Bebop. Cowboy Bebop is what I like to call The Godfather of anime. Just like The Godfather showed gangster dramas could be more than just pulpy entertainment, Cowboy Bebop showed anime could be thought provoking, stylish, and down right tear jerking, and Cowboy Bebop: the Movie, is more than worthy than being associated with the series. It delivers all the slick action, cool dialogue, and thought provoking themes of the series in a 2 hour time slot. Another cool thing about the film is the fact that even if you haven't seen the show, you can still enjoy it. It's a film for just about anyone, but I'd still recommend watching the series first. Set between episodes 22 and 23, this film follows the crew of the Bebop as they try to uncover the true behind a series of mysterious bombing on civilian areas. It may sound basic, but it gets a lot more complex than that. Basically telling you anymore would spoil the film. I do feel some areas of the film are a little heavy handed though, but it's not enough to take away from the overall experience. Fans of anime will love it, and those newer to the genre should find enjoyment as well.

Cowboy Bebop: The Movie is the way that all movie adaptions of a series should be. It's so faithful to the original series that it feels like an elongated episode but not to the point where it feels stretched out and adds enough to it to make the leap to film necessary and that's an amazing job and one of the best things it accomplishes. 

Another great thing about it is that you can watch this without having watched the show, although, unless you didn't know there was a show, even though it has 'The Movie' in the title, I don't know why would want to. It starts off just like any other episode, it has a cool introduction and then smoothly transitions into the main plot. The story of the movie is very good, it fits the feel of the series and has quite a lot of interesting character development and shocking moments. I liked the villain, he was just cool, something I don't usually pay attention to, I don't normally just like a villain just because they're cool. I need to know about them in order to like them and in typical fashion we do learn about him and he does have a very interesting backstory which is actually quite tragic and it just makes him more cool and interesting. The Bebop crew are still the same as ever with the same excellent voice cast and it's great to see more of them. And hey the three old guys even get a cameo!

The animation is excellent and the action scenes are fluid and look beautiful. The soundtrack is also fantastic, which is just like anime, the bebop is still as amazing as ever, although, there were perhaps one too many vocal songs for my liking but they fit the scenes they were in so I guess it makes sense. The only complaint I really have is that I think the movie finished a little too quickly, the big fight scene was still going and there was only about 4 minutes left, I thought the ending was going to be cut off. However, it did wrap up well and it wasn't a bad ending, I'd just have liked it to slow down a bit. So, I'd have like the movie to go on longer, not really a complaint and having 2 hours more Bebop is already brilliant so I guess I shouldn't complain. 

The only thing I think non-fans will question if they do decide to watch this, for some reason, is that Ed doesn't really do anything and they might question her point. True that she didn't do a whole lot in the anime either, besides getting details for the crew but at least we know where she came from and a little bit about her past. Which is a problem I have with the show, after she was introduced and needed in episode 9, it seemed like the creators forgot she was even in the show, even I did when I first watched it, she showed up again after being absent and I went, 'oh yeah! She's here!', I still love her though, I think she's a brilliant character. 

It is more than worthy to be connected with the main series and I'm very happy that this was made and was successful as it was. Cowboy Bebop: The Movie is the perfect companion piece to a brilliant show and it's just a cool movie,  I will be watching this many more times in the future. See You Space Cowboy.

I am a HUGE fan of the Cowboy Bebop TV series. Because of this, I have the right to say that Cowboy Bebop: The Movie was a MASSIVE disappointment. The brilliant music, fun characters and action sequences were here. But it still has unfulfilled potential (barely any space scenes), slow pacing, and an ending filled with plot holes. Overall, It just felt like one giant filler episode. If you haven't watched the TV series, you need to! It's one of my favorite animes of all time. Watch that instead of this. The movie is not awful, but it certainly doesn't live up to the show.

An ominous terrorist attack imperils the denizens of a late-21st century metropolis. The bomb has a lethal effect on the bloodstream of its victims, but scientists can't correlate it to any known virus or nerve gas. Naturally, it's up to our three favorite bounty hunters to track down the perpetrator before he can strike again. The plot of this movie doesn't break any new ground, but the stakes are high enough to make things seem like something more than an extended version of the Cowboy Bebop TV show. Like the celebrated anime series it's an extension of, the critical pleasures of Cowboy Bebop: The Movie can be derived from its cheeky dialogue, well-paced action sequences, pugnacious soundtrack, and cutting edge animation.
The movie doesn't quite reflect how fantastic the series is on a regular basis, but it's still watchable.

I sat there amused by the characters mostly Spike Spiegel, the cool dialogue, and the plot involving a mad evil terrorist. If you are not a fan of Anime or Japanese cartoons, I suggest stay away from Cowboy Bebop, for you will be hooked!

All this aside, it is well voice acted, well plotted, and truly badass.

EW pretty much sums up my thoughts: "Honors the affectless beauty of the original anime art and maintains the outlaw boppiness of the series concept." 4/5 Series fans may still 'gripe' that the movie really just feels like a seriously decompressed episode where the big action is spread too far between long shots with inner monologues and flashbacks (much like Drive did with too many action sequences broken up by ultra-quiet brooding scenes where there's no dramatic tension, and action that just unfolded before seems to have been forgotten.)

Apparently, Bob Dylan Isn't an [i]Otaku[/i]

I've never seen the TV show.  The top two reviews on Rotten Tomatoes right now are in conflict about whether this is a good thing or not.  One says it's a great introduction to the show.  The other says that, like with [i]Serenity[/i], you won't like it if you haven't seen the TV show.  Only I really liked [i]Serenity[/i] the first time I saw it, and I hadn't seen the TV show of that, either.  Then again, I have a certain ability to trace the threads that don't actually appear.  I mean, the only question I had after the end of [i]Serenity[/i] was why the show was called [i]Firefly[/i].  Similarly, I don't entirely get the reason the anime is called [i]Cowboy Bebop[/i], and I'm suspecting the exchange is somehow off and that dollars on the show aren't the same as current dollars, but in general, I was able to pick up on most of what was going on and didn't feel like I was missing anything in particular.

We're on Mars.  Spike Spiegel (Kôichi Yamadera), Jet Black (Unshô Ishizuka), and Faye Valentine (Megumi Hayashibara) are all bounty hunters.  Spike and Jet are doing some relatively piddling work.  Faye is going after a minor hacker, only it turns into some kind of major thing.  There's a guy named Vincent Volaju (Tsutomu Isobe).  Despite a ban against it, the government of Mars has been dabbling in experimental nanotechnology.  However, Vincent has been infected with experimental anti-nanotechnology.  Of course.  And he's planning to destroy the government, etc., of Mars by putting the nanotechnology in the water supply, which will pretty much destroy all the people.  At least, I think that was what was going on.  Anyway, the government of Mars is offering a pretty enormous bounty for Vincent, and even if they weren't, Our Heroes would kind of like the entire population of Mars to not die.  So they have to spread the anti-nanotechnology over the entire population in order to thwart Vincent.

Okay, no, I wasn't able to work out everything that was going on.  For one thing, it was just too hot.  I don't deal well with heat.  For another, I actually watched this yesterday, and I didn't get around to writing a review until just now after having not watched anything but episodes of TV shows today.  However, I have to tell you, the characters aren't as in-depth as the characters of [i]Serenity[/i], and while there does seem to be a lot of backstory, I'm not sure how much it all mattered.  For all I didn't actually need to know it, the backstory of [i]Serenity[/i] was very clearly shaping every frame of that film, and it didn't feel as though this was the case here.  It's a bunch of bounty hunters on Mars, and a government has done a thing that it shouldn't.  This is not complicated.  It's interesting, and I may get around to the TV show at some point (probably after the heat breaks), but that doesn't mean it required a lot of thought, either.

Apparently, if you know what you're looking for, you can tell exactly what guns everyone is using and work out what the planes are in the sequence at the end.  (Why all those antique planes are on Mars is another thing that never gets explained, however; at least one of those planes is old even by our standards, and this movie is set some time in our future.)  It certainly is true that the animation is beautifully detailed.  I find that people who don't watch anime tend to have a specific perception of what all the art is like, and the art in this movie isn't like that.  I mean, okay, there's Ed (Aoi Tada), who's a bit chibi and about whom I would have liked some more information, but she isn't even onscreen very often.  Spike, Faye, Jet, and Electra (Ai Kobayashi) all look pretty much human--more realistic than a lot of Western animation.  This is the product of people really trying to make the characters look like people, not like caricatures.  Some of the backgrounds are frankly stunning, too.

No, I don't see this as the kind of anime that I would sit down and watch just for pleasure.  I'm not one of those people who will watch anime just because it's anime, despite my incredible distaste of people who won't watch anime just because it's anime.  In general, I pick and choose.  The characters in this seem to have a lot of potential that's probably better explored in the TV show, where there's more room to do it.  However, I'm not sure I'm terribly interested in them.  It's a science fiction show, technically, but--again not unlike [i]Serenity[/i]--its science fiction core isn't completely relevant to the course of the story.  That's okay; science fiction can be as much a setting as a genre, if you do it right.  That's one of the reasons I have such a hard time finding the border between sci-fi and fantasy; [i]Star Wars[/i] only stays on the sci-fi side of the line because spaceships, really.  This is mostly just action, except it's action set on Mars.  And drawn by Japanese people.

As a fan of the show I truly enjoyed the whole movie. As a viewer I enjoyed the character relationships and story that Watanabe creates. With a great choice of Voice actors and some beautiful animation it is easily one of my favorite films

The animation is as smooth as silk, the soundtrack is a bit weak (compared to the series), but let's brush that aside for a moment, and focus on the min attraction: the characters. Spike Spiegel is a lanky, fuzzy-haired cowboy, who is suprisingly good at martial arts and what's more: he's super badass. Jet is the (more or less) rational one on the crew, the ex-cop with a gruff voice and a fake arm. Faye Valentine is the curvy one, who is both delicate and tough, and a bit temeramental. Radical Ed is... well, he's Ed. A teenage girl with wild hacking skills and an eccentric demeanor, she's pure gold every second she's on screen.
I liked the film, mostly because of the crew, but the plot, the style also had me hooked.

It's definitely Bebop, but at the same time, it's not. Gone is the soulful jazz that powers the unbelievably cool anime, it also seems to drop the noir backings for a decidedly more detective like story. All this is fine, because Spike is busy being Spike, but if the heart of the show was here, this could have been so much more.

Oh look, it's an anime movie that is ACTUALLY GOOD.

If you have never watched the TV series, this movie is a great introduction to the show, Cowboy Bebop. It's full of action, the characters are smart mouthed, the animation is well done and the stays true to the original anime series.
Not as good as the tv series. But it in someway maintains the charm and action of the show, while still giving us something fresh and entertaining to view.

Cowboy Bebop is considered to be the best anime series of all time, and the feature-length film may be one of the best Japanese animated films of all time as well. The film's story is like a feature-length episode of TV series with the inclusion of songs that fit the tone, and the magnificent voice acting by the original cast (both Japanese and English). It's intense, comical, and enjoyable at the same time.

Note: fans of the series, watch this film between episodes 22 and 23 of the series as that is the time of which it is set and is not the conclusion to the series.

You have to give the creators of the greatest anime series of all time some breathing space.
Though this is not their shining moment, I'm pretty sure this isn't the thing they want sitting on top of their Christmas tree.
I have to give props to the cast, the team, the characters and the animation, it was the story that was a little bit disappointing. Just give me one of their regular yahoos with a straight-up fight in the end and not some huge conspiracy. It felt as though they were trying to cram every single aspect of the series into one movie.
Don't do that. You for it like that, you end up with a Star Wars prequel.
The reason why the series was infinitely better was because each episode was an individual, well-told story focusing on, like, one thing, and not some huge, sort of rushed story that you don't really care about.
I will say this, three and a half stars or four because I respect the name too much. Sure, biased, sue me. It could have been better! Hopefully something good from the same makers will come along shortly and reinvigorate my day to day life.

Blah.  This is a waste of time.  This is one of the dullest bounty hunter films I've ever seen, though don't get me wrong -- there are a few exciting, interesting scenes.  The opening bank robbery sequence, for example; that's the kind of entertainment I wish for during the remainder of the film.  Instead, the action scenes are dry and the characters are incredibly bland.  Also, I know this is Japanese, but honestly, the soundtrack is one of the most laughable things I have ever heard.  Pass this up.

As I mentioned in my first review of this movie, I loved this movie and that still hasn't changed. Everything is good about this movie: the story, the crisp animation, the characters and music. What also makes this movie great is that its also accessible to people who havent seen the tv show that this movie is based on. 

The movie plays out more like an extended episode of the series and it follows more of the formula of the tv show which is very fun to watch. 4 out of 5 stars (SEE YOU SPACE COWBOY)

This is how you make an anime movie, I am a big fan of the series, so this is great. We have everything we love about Cowboy Bebop (The Music, the action scenes, the amazing characterization) brought together into this movie, and no anime movie has ended with a better song than this, Gotta Knock a Little Harder!

To describe it in as short a time as possible:
It has scary-good animation, with the exception of Akira, I have never seen such fluid movements in an anime before. As per the series, it has an awesome soundtrack, with tons of bluesy-rock and funky-jazz music. It has plenty of time to be philosophical, yet doesn't get too rant-y on us *coughs* N.G.E. *coughs* G.I.T.S. *coughs*. It also doesn't sacrifice character development or action either. In other words, it is a very well-rounded film that, despite the critics consensus, you don't have to be an otaku to watch and enjoy.
extremely enjoyable even if you have not seen the T.V. series....but people who are close-minded when it comes to anime need not to bother in the first place.

A freaking great anime In my top 3 for sure...This is a must see for anyone. It takes place between episodes 23 and 24 of the series which is also in my top three for anime series. The music in the movie is one of the best aspects along with a nice storyline deep characters and nice blend of action, dark comedy and slight philosophy. Check this movie out.

I'm a huge Cowboy Bebop fan.  No matter how many mixed reviews I read, I knew that this movie could not fail me.  It didn't.  It didn't blow mind.  If you compare the series to the movie... well the movie just falls short.  Cowboy Bebop is such a wonderful series, and the movie just feels out of place (which it is).  The movie feels like an unnecessary encore.  It is a good watch though.  I thought the illustrations were awesome.  If you are a 'Bebop fan you probably will appreciate the movie.  If you have never watched an episode of Cowboy Bebop, don't even bother watching the movie.

Haven't seen the series so I haven't got the connection with characters that may be necessary to fully appreciate this film. Still, I can't help feeling that the lack of emotional connection was due to the episodic nature of the film, which, like a jazz record, is based more around mood and tone than narrative structure. I also never really understood the motivation of the bad guy, whose entire premise seems to be 'he kind of looks like Bob Dylan, let's get him to say mysterious stuff which sounds like it could be deep and meaningful'. Unfortunately, Dylan himself is much better at formulating nonsense with the appearance of depth, and his usually comes with a nicer tune, too.
Would love to see a live action version. Would not love to see it with Keanu as Spike.
I like anything and everything connected to this anime series.  This movie is no exception.
superb series,comparitvely average movie but still decent enough to be worth watching and if you are an anime nut like me, worth buying to place alongside your Bebop boxset :)
Love the series, the weird characters & great sound tracks ... the movie is beautifully crafted (maybe a bit too long :)).

Embodies everything I loved about Cowboy Bebop. The chemistry of the crew, the Scifi elements, Spike's martial arts prowess and delicious animation while still retaining that slick bounty hunter feel.

Someday though I'll have to climb over that lame melodramatic mountain that seems present in all Anime. The main antagonist is such a quack, boohoo everyone died except me! I don't know about my past so I have to kill large amounts of people! Please.

The thing to like about the TV show is that the episodes are short and sweet, while giving plenty of depth to the characters. This is too long, and doesn't explore any of the characters. The dialogue and direction are still "Bebop - Brilliant" which slightly redeems this one. Don't get me wrong though it's still boring.

Written with an air of brilliance. Behind the terrorism and futuristic atmosphere a story about one man's struggle to accept reality is reflected by the villain. This is not just an action or a thriller but a deep look into the protagonists psyche without love. The real story is overlooked because of many unnecessary scenes which reveal the actions of the Martian government. I'd suggest anyone that didn't like this to seriously re-watch and listen very closely to Spike when he speaks. Everything from "We're not cops" to "He was always alone" reflects deeply the underlying story.

I remember loving this movie the first time I saw it. Watching it again years later, it felt kinda slow and definitely nowhere as interesting as the show. Still, good music and some pretty sweet action.

rt_summary: Cocky Spike Spiegel and the crew of his spaceship, Bebop, an intrepid band of bounty hunters, land on Mars in the year 2071 chasing an enormous cash reward. The four-person team, also including looming cyborg Jet Black, fearless Faye Valentine and tech expert Edward, are in search of ex-military officer Vincent. The former hero has become a biological terrorist with an arsenal of devastating nano-bots that he'll let loose on Alba City on the night before Halloween if his demands aren't met.
